Prompt:
Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'human aging' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. Aging is a natural process that happens to all humans. It starts when we are babies. Our bodies grow and change. We get bigger, stronger, and smarter. But then, our bodies start to slow down. Our skin wrinkles, and our hair turns gray or falls out. We may not see or hear as well as before. Our bodies may not work as fast or as well. This is all part of getting older. But even when we are old, we can still learn new things and enjoy life.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'human aging' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. Use the word 'we' to refer to humans generally, and the word 'they' to refer to scientists.

We grow up, then we grow old. Our bodies change. Our skin gets wrinkles. Our hair turns gray or falls out. Our bones get weak. We can't move as fast as we used to. Scientists study aging. They want to understand why we change. Maybe one day, they will find a way to help us live longer and stay healthier.

Text:
Example 1:
Cat and Dog walk. They walk in their village. Then they see an egg. The egg is in the grass. The egg is alone in the grass. The egg is all alone. Cat and Dog walk to a bird. They ask the bird, "Is this your egg?" But the bird says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the owl. Maybe it is his egg." Cat and Dog walk to the owl. They ask the owl, "Is this your egg?" But the owl says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the goose. Maybe it is her egg." Cat and Dog walk to the goose. They ask the goose, "Is this your egg?" But the goose says, "No, that is not my egg. Ask the two ducks. Maybe it is their egg." Cat and Dog walk to the two ducks. They ask the two ducks, "Is this your egg?" But the two ducks say, "No, that is not our egg." Then the egg breaks.

Example 2:
The Sun’s light shines on Earth. The light makes our air, land, and water warm. But some things get
warmer than others.
Pretend it is a sunny day. If you wore a black shirt, you would feel hot. But if you wore a white shirt, you wouldn’t feel as hot. The dark color absorbs more of the Sun’s energy. That makes the black shirt warm.
Light colors reflect more of the Sun’s energy. This makes the white shirt cooler to wear. See for yourself! You need a piece of black paper and a piece of white paper. You also need two thermometers and a lamp. Ask an adult to help you.
Fold the black paper so it makes a pocket. Do the same thing to the white paper. Next, put a thermometer into the black pocket. Do the same thing to the white pocket. Then put the pockets under the lamp. Turn the lamp on, and wait for 10 minutes. Then check the thermometers.
Which pocket got hotter — the black pocket or the white one? Do you know why?

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'human aging' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. The paragraph should discuss the causes of aging, including both internal (genetic) and external (environmental) factors.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'human aging' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. Aging is a normal process in humans. As time passes, humans grow older. Their skin becomes wrinkled, and their hair turns gray or white. They may also lose some of their strength and energy. But aging can be different for everyone. Some people may age quickly, while others might age more slowly.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'human aging' targeting the same readability level (Early Elementary), limited to 100 words. Here's my attempt:

Every person gets older. This is called aging. It happens very slowly. You can't see it from one day to the next. But if you look at pictures from many years ago, you can see the changes. As people get older, their hair can turn gray or white. Their skin can become wrinkled. They might need glasses to see. But aging is not all bad. Older people can teach younger ones many things. They can share stories and wisdom.
